title: Paula Szkody
text:
Paula Szkody (born July 17, 1948) is a professor in the Department of <a href="Astronomy">Astronomy</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> in <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>.
Early life and education.
Szkody was born on July 17, 1948, in <a href="Detroit">Detroit, Michigan</a>. She earned her B.A. degree in <a href="astrophysics">astrophysics</a> at <a href="Michigan%20State%20University">Michigan State University</a> in 1970, and her Ph.D. in <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> in 1975.
Work.
Paula Szkody specializes in <a href="Cataclysmic%20variable%20star">cataclysmic variable</a> stars, which are binary star systems that periodically undergo energetic outbursts. She is an active participant in the <a href="Sloan%20Digital%20Sky%20Survey">Sloan Digital Sky Survey</a> (SDSS) searching for new <a href="dwarf%20nova">dwarf nova</a>e and has worked with the <a href="Rossi%20X-ray%20Timing%20Explorer">XTE</a>, <a href="Advanced%20Satellite%20for%20Cosmology%20and%20Astrophysics">ASCA</a>, <a href="ROSAT">ROSAT</a>, <a href="International%20Ultraviolet%20Explorer">IUE</a>, <a href="Hubble%20Space%20Telescope">HST</a>, <a href="Extreme%20Ultraviolet%20Explorer">EUVE</a> and <a href="XMM-Newton">XMM-Newton</a> space missions.
Activities.
In 2005 she became the editor-in-chief of the astronomical <a href="Academic%20journal">journal</a> "<a href="Publications%20of%20the%20Astronomical%20Society%20of%20the%20Pacific">Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific</a> (PASP)". She is also very active in professional-amateur collaboration, especially in conjunction with the <a href="American%20Association%20of%20Variable%20Star%20Observers">American Association of Variable Star Observers</a>, for whom she has served both as an officer on the board (2003-2009) and, for the term 2007-09, as President of the organization.
Honors and awards.
In 1978, she was awarded the <a href="Annie%20Jump%20Cannon%20Award%20in%20Astronomy">Annie Jump Cannon Award in Astronomy</a> by the <a href="American%20Astronomical%20Society">American Astronomical Society</a>.
As of 1994, she is a fellow of the <a href="American%20Association%20for%20the%20Advancement%20of%20Science">American Association for the Advancement of Science</a>.
A minor planet has been named after her.
